    <item>
      <title>Nissan Throws a Lifeline to Scandal-Stricken Mitsubishi</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/stricken-by-fuel-economy-scandal-mitsubishi-turns-to-nissan.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/stricken-by-fuel-economy-scandal-mitsubishi-turns-to-nissan.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/stricken-by-fuel-economy-scandal-mitsubishi-turns-to-nissan.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/13/business/13db-nissan/13db-nissan-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Carlos Ghosn, left, chairman of Nissan, with Mitsubishi’s chairman, Osamu Masuko, at a news conference Thursday in Yokohama, Japan.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Franck Robichon/European Pressphoto Agency</media:credit>
      <description>Nissan will buy a 34 percent stake in the automaker for $2.2 billion, which could help Mitsubishi cope with the impact of cheating on mileage tests.</description>
      <dc:creator>JONATHAN SOBLE</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 10:11:36 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Automobiles</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Mitsubishi Motor Corp</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Nissan Motor Co</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Fuel Efficiency</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Antitrust in the Age of Amazon</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/office-depot-staples-merger-antitrust-amazon.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/office-depot-staples-merger-antitrust-amazon.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/office-depot-staples-merger-antitrust-amazon.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/13/business/13retail-web1/13retail-web1-moth-v3.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Big companies shop for products like toner cartridges differently than individuals do – and that’s a reason why the Federal Trade Commission blocked the Office Depot-Staples merger.</media:description>
      <media:credit>James Nieves/The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>Pens matter. Ink does not. The blocking of the Staples-Office Depot union illustrates the complications the age of Amazon has created in the retail industry.</description>
      <dc:creator>RACHEL ABRAMS</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 14:27:03 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Office Supplies and Equipment</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Federal Trade Commission</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Office Depot Inc.</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Staples Inc</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>David Cameron Leads a Call to Thwart Financial Corruption</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/world/europe/britain-cameron-corruption.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/world/europe/britain-cameron-corruption.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/world/europe/britain-cameron-corruption.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <description>Mr. Cameron, representing Britain, outlined measures to fight offshore tax evasion as he met with Secretary of State John Kerry and other leaders in London.</description>
      <dc:creator>STEPHEN CASTLE and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:43:46 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Cameron, David</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Corruption (Institutional)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Great Britain</category>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">International Relations</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Real Estate and Housing (Residential)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Tax Evasion</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Kerry, John</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">United States International Relations</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Dong Energy, Wind Power Operator, to Pursue I.P.O. in Copenhagen</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/denmark-wind-dong-energy-ipo.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/denmark-wind-dong-energy-ipo.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/denmark-wind-dong-energy-ipo.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/13/business/13db-danishipo/13db-danishipo-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>The Danish utility Dong Energy is the world’s largest offshore wind energy operator.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Jeff J. Mitchell/Getty Images</media:credit>
      <description>The company, which is the world’s largest offshore wind energy operator, plans a listing on Nasdaq in Copenhagen this summer.</description>
      <dc:creator>CHAD BRAY</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 08:01:20 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Initial Public Offerings</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Wind Power</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Dong Energy</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Former Banker Sentenced in Insider Trading Case in Britain</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/former-banker-sentenced-in-insider-trading-case-in-britain.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/former-banker-sentenced-in-insider-trading-case-in-britain.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/former-banker-sentenced-in-insider-trading-case-in-britain.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <description>Martyn Dodgson, a former investment banker, was sentenced to four-and-a-half years in prison after being convicted on an insider trading charge.</description>
      <dc:creator>CHAD BRAY</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 12:44:57 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Insider Trading</category>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Financial Conduct Authority (Great Britain)</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>R.B.S. Will Not Face Charges Over Rights Issue in 2008</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/scotland-rbs-decline-criminal-charges.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/scotland-rbs-decline-criminal-charges.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/business/dealbook/scotland-rbs-decline-criminal-charges.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <description>Scottish prosecutors said there was “insufficient evidence” to pursue senior figures at the bank over the raising of about $17 billion just before its rescue.</description>
      <dc:creator>CHAD BRAY</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 14:06:25 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Banking and Financial Institutions</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Royal Bank of Scotland PLC</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Regulation and Deregulation of Industry</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Britain Plans to Tighten Oversight of the BBC in New Charter</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/world/europe/britain-plans-to-tighten-oversight-of-the-bbc-in-new-charter.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/world/europe/britain-plans-to-tighten-oversight-of-the-bbc-in-new-charter.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/world/europe/britain-plans-to-tighten-oversight-of-the-bbc-in-new-charter.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/13/world/13BBC-web2/13BBC-web2-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>The BBC headquarters in London. The proposed charter secures the BBC’s funding through the next charter and will allow the license fee paid by most Britons, frozen at 145.50 pounds a year, to rise with inflation.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Peter Nicholls/Reuters</media:credit>
      <description>The government, presenting its plans for the BBC’s future, pulled back from radical changes but urged the publicly funded broadcaster to be more “distinctive” in its programming.</description>
      <dc:creator>STEVEN ERLANGER</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:35:42 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">British Broadcasting Corp</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">News and News Media</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Politics and Government</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Television</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Whittingdale, John</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Canada Fire Deals Staggering Blow to Oil Sands Industry and Economy</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/energy-environment/canadas-oil-sands-industry-staggers-after-a-devastating-fire.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/energy-environment/canadas-oil-sands-industry-staggers-after-a-devastating-fire.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/energy-environment/canadas-oil-sands-industry-staggers-after-a-devastating-fire.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/12/business/12canadaecon1/12canadaecon1-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Smoke filling the street in deserted downtown Fort McMurray in Alberta, Canada, last week. A devastating fire in the region continues to rage.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Tyler Hicks/The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>Companies either curbed production or shut down completely when the blaze struck Fort McMurray, Alberta, in an economic setback to the region.</description>
      <dc:creator>IAN AUSTEN</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 20:50:26 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Fires and Firefighters</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Oil Sands</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Fort McMurray (Alberta)</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Wildfires</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Economic Conditions and Trends</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Canada</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Unemployment</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Evacuations and Evacuees</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Alberta (Canada)</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Google to Ban All Payday Loan Ads</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/google-to-ban-all-payday-loan-ads.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/google-to-ban-all-payday-loan-ads.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/google-to-ban-all-payday-loan-ads.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/11/business/12xp-google/12xp-google-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Google’s ban on payday loan ads will take effect July 13.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Jeff Chiu/Associated Press</media:credit>
      <description>The web giant said the move was to protect its users from such lending, which often leads to unaffordable repayment terms and financial harm.</description>
      <dc:creator>CHRISTINE HAUSER</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 18:40:32 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Google Inc</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Consumer Protection</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Credit and Debt</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Advertising and Marketing</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Payday Loans</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Online Advertising</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Mitsubishi Cheating Scandal Expands to More Models</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/international/mitsubishi-cheating-scandal-expands-to-more-models.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/international/mitsubishi-cheating-scandal-expands-to-more-models.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/international/mitsubishi-cheating-scandal-expands-to-more-models.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/11/business/12MITSUBISHI/12MITSUBISHI-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Osamu Masuko, center, chairman of Mitsubishi, at a news conference in Tokyo on Wednesday.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Eugene Hoshiko/Associated Press</media:credit>
      <description>The company has said it used improper methods to test fuel economy for 25 years, and on Wednesday it said every model it sold in Japan was affected.</description>
      <dc:creator>JONATHAN SOBLE</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 05:29:40 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Mitsubishi Motor Corp</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Fuel Efficiency</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Japan</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Automobiles</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Cheating</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Nissan Motor Co</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Frauds and Swindling</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>E.U. Regulators Block Merger of British Mobile Carriers on Competition Grounds</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/international/three-o2-merger-blocked-eu.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/international/three-o2-merger-blocked-eu.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/international/three-o2-merger-blocked-eu.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/05/nytnow/05EUtelecome/05EUtelecome-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>The Munich offices of the Spanish telecommunications giant Telefónica, which owns O2.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Sven Hoppe/European Pressphoto Agency</media:credit>
      <description>The acquisition of O2 by Hutchison Whampoa, the owner of the operator Three, would have harmed consumer choice, the bloc’s antitrust chief said.</description>
      <dc:creator>MARK SCOTT</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 10:47:55 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Telephones and Telecommunications</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Hutchison Whampoa Limited</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_org_all">Telefonica SA</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Canadian Hotel Investment Trust to Be Sold for $1.6 Billion</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/dealbook/hotels-canada-innvest-bluesky.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/dealbook/hotels-canada-innvest-bluesky.html</guid>

    <item>
      <title>Takata Looks to Overhaul Division Responsible for Airbag Defects</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/takata-airbags-earnings.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/takata-airbags-earnings.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/business/takata-airbags-earnings.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/12/business/12takata/12takata-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Yoichiro Nomura, Takata’s chief financial officer, arriving at a news conference Wednesday at the Tokyo Stock Exchange.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Toru Hanai/Reuters</media:credit>
      <description>The embattled Japanese company said it was looking to restructure its business, as it confirmed a net loss of $120 million for the fiscal year ending in March.</description>

    <item>
      <title>Toyota Sees End to Run of Record Annual Profits on Yen Strength</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2016/05/11/business/11reuters-toyota-results.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2016/05/11/business/11reuters-toyota-results.html</guid>
      <description>Toyota Motor Corp forecast a bigger-than-expected 35 percent tumble in net profit for the current year due to the sharp appreciation of the yen, ending three straight years of record profits driven in part by a weak currency.</description>
      <dc:creator>REUTERS</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 08:42:36 GMT</pubDate>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/nyt_org_all">Honda Motor Co Ltd|HMC|NYSE</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/nyt_org_all">Thomson Reuters Corporation|TRI|NYSE</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/nyt_org_all">Toyota Motor Corp|TM|NYSE</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/nyt_org_all">Volkswagen AG|VLKAY|Other OTC</category>
    </item>
    <item>
      <title>Credit Suisse Swings to First-Quarter Loss on Turbulent Markets</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/business/dealbook/credit-suisse-earnings.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/business/dealbook/credit-suisse-earnings.html</guid>

      <media:description>Tidjane Thiam, chief executive of Credit Suisse, is in the midst of an extensive overhaul of the Swiss bank.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Arnd Wiegmann/Reuters</media:credit>

      <title>Turkey’s President Erdogan Fails to Silence German Publisher</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/world/europe/turkeys-president-erdogan-loses-injunction-against-german-publisher.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>

      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/11/world/11springer-web2/11springer-web2-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Tuesday in Ankara. The Turkish president has tried to silence his critics at home and abroad.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Reuters</media:credit>
      <description>A German court rejected a request by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan for an injunction against the chief executive of Axel Springer over his support for a comedian who lampooned the Turkish leader.</description>

      <media:credit>Anheuser-Busch</media:credit>

    <item>
      <title>Clinton Son-in-Law’s Firm Is Said to Close Greece Hedge Fund</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/business/dealbook/clinton-son-in-laws-firm-is-said-to-close-greece-hedge-fund.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/business/dealbook/clinton-son-in-laws-firm-is-said-to-close-greece-hedge-fund.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/business/dealbook/clinton-son-in-laws-firm-is-said-to-close-greece-hedge-fund.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/11/business/11DB-HEDGE/11DB-HEDGE-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Former President Bill Clinton and his son-in-law, Marc Mezvinsky, at an event in March 2015 supporting equality for women. A Greece-focused fund run by Mr. Mezvinsky’s firm is said to have lost nearly 90 percent of its value, and sources say it will be shutting down.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Spencer Platt/Getty Images</media:credit>
      <description>Eaglevale Partners, an investment firm co-founded by Marc Mezvinsky, Chelsea Clinton’s husband, is said to be shutting down a fund betting on a Greek revival.</description>
      <dc:creator>ALEXANDRA STEVENSON and MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN</dc:creator>
      <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 23:20:07 GMT</pubDate>

      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_geo">Greece</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">Hedge Funds</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/nyt_per">Blankfein, Lloyd C</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/des">European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )</category>
      <category domain="http://www.nytimes.com/namespaces/keywords/mdes">Government Bonds</category>
    </item>

      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/13/business/13STEWART/13STEWART-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>The American International Group says it will cut its hedge fund holdings in half by the end of 2017</media:description>
      <media:credit>Brendan McDermid/Reuters</media:credit>
      <description>The high-reward, low-risk promises of hedge funds failed to materialize, and many insurance companies are unwinding their positions.</description>

    <item>
      <title>State of the Art: Facebook’s Bias Is Built-In, and Bears Watching</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/technology/facebooks-bias-is-built-in-and-bears-watching.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/technology/facebooks-bias-is-built-in-and-bears-watching.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/technology/facebooks-bias-is-built-in-and-bears-watching.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/12/business/subSTATEJP/subSTATEJP-moth.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>Mark Zuckerberg, the Facebook chief. The company says it would never try to manipulate elections.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Jim Wilson/The New York Times</media:credit>
      <description>Its algorithms are as infused with bias as any human decision, but neither it nor its audience thinks of Facebook as a news organization with editorial responsibilities.</description>

    <item>
      <title>Economic Scene: Government Must Play a Role Again in Job Creation</title>
      <link>http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/business/economy/as-jobs-vanish-forgetting-what-government-is-for.html?partner=rss&emc=rss</link>
      <guid isPermaLink="true">http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/business/economy/as-jobs-vanish-forgetting-what-government-is-for.html</guid>
      <atom:link rel="standout" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/11/business/economy/as-jobs-vanish-forgetting-what-government-is-for.html?partner=rss&emc=rss"/>
      <media:content url="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/05/10/business/11porter1/11porter1-moth-v2.jpg" medium="image" height="151" width="151"/>
      <media:description>The workers of the Bement Miles Pond Company, circa 1920. The new industrial economy at the turn of the last century created jobs that were generally more productive and better paid than those it left behind.</media:description>
      <media:credit>Bettman Archives, via Getty Images</media:credit>
      <description>What has stopped the United States from creating better-paying jobs is not a lack of ideas but an encrusted ideological opposition to government activism.</description>
      <dc:creator>EDUARDO PORTER</dc:creator>
